page.title: 03Landscape around Cilcain (2)
page.content: The Alyn Gorge: A landscape feature here is the steep-sided 'gorge' which the River Alyn has cut through the limestone ridge. It is believed that the course of the river was diverted to this north-eastward line during the Ice Age, when the original northerly course may have been blocked by ice. The sides of the gorge are steep, rather than sheer, and are mostly covered by deciduous woodland. The Dry River-Bed: Since limestone is permeable, much river-water sinks underground into 'swallow-holes' in the rock. In periods of low flow all water may disappear further upstream and the whole length of the river-bed in this area may be dry for several weeks each summer. The farm at the Cilcain end of the gorge is appropriately named 'Hesp Alyn' _ Welsh for 'Dry Alyn'.
